prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Band 7: The Band 7 frequency 300 GHz is highly sensitive, avoids telluric absorption, and corresponds to ~300 microns rest at z = 2.3, which is ideally near the peak of the spectral energy distribution of starbursting ULIRGs (e.g., Elbaz et al. 2002, Chary & Elbaz 2001) while also sufficiently longward of this peak where reprocessed quasar light (by hot dust) is negligible (Netzer et al. 2007, Farrah et al. 2007 and 2012, Lutz et al. 2008, Beelen et al. 2006, Kirkpatrick et al. 2012). Figure 2 shows the position of Band 7 in the SED of the local ULIRG Arp 220, as it would appear at redshifts 2.0 and 2.7 (from Silva et al. 1998, redshifted using a standard cosmology).
C34-7 array configuration: The 0.135 arcsec angular resolution and max recoverable scale of 2.6 arcsec correspond to ~1.1 kpc and ~22 kpc in the source frame, respectively. These spatial scales are well matched to quasar host galaxies at redshift 2.0-2.7. In particular, if the FeLoBAL hosts are, as expected, in a young evolutionary phase, they will have strong starbursts that span physical diameters 2-10 kpc like other ULIRGs and SMGs at these redshifts (Bothwell et al. 2010, Rujopakarn et al. 2011). The quasar hosts might also have disturbed morphologies or double nuclei indicating ongoing mergers, as is common in local ULIRGs on scales of ~2.4-15 kpc (Surace et al. 2000, Yun et al. 2013). Our observations will resolve these structures to determine if the star formation is mainly in the nuclear regions, associated with the quasars, or spatially distributed perhaps in secondary nuclei or other star forming knots.
RMS 0.06 mJy sensitivity: We choose this sensitivity to measure star formation rates down to SFR ~ 15 Mo/yr at the 4-sigma level per 1.1 kpc beam at the redshifts of our targets. We adopt the 4-sigma flux limit of 0.24 mJy for secure detections and assume the star formation produces a typical ULIRG-like far-IR spectral shape (Elbaz et al. 2002, Kirkpatrick et al. 2012, Fig.2). The 0.24 mJy flux threshold at 300 microns rest then corresponds to a total infrared luminosity of L_IR = 1.5 x 10^11 Lo per beam (for a standard cosmology), which is ~3x smaller than the smallest L_IR surface density reported for z > 2 ULIRGs and SMGs (Rujopakarn et al. 2011) and ~6x smaller than the minimum total L_IR used to define "ULIRGs" (>10^12 L_o, see also Arp 220 in Figure 2). It corresponds to SFR ~ 15 M_o/yr using a Galactic initial mass function and standard L_IR to SFR conversions (Kennicutt 1998, Chabrier 2005). In comparison, our quasar targets are all exceptionally luminous. The FeLoBALs are predicted to reside in massive young galaxies with major starbursts like well-studied high-luminosity ULIRGs at z ~ 1-2 that have L_IR ~ 5-10 x 10^12 L_o corresponding to SFR ~ 500-1000 M_o/yr (refs above, also Yun et al. 2013, Elbaz et al. 2002). The non-BAL control quasars might have similarly large SFRs or they might be weaker owing to a more advanced age. Either way, our observations will obtain the first accurate measurements of the spatial distributions of SFRs around z > 2 quasars.
Band 7 only: We will observe only in Band 7 to maximize the science return with a minimum cost in valuable telescope time. Additional continuum points are not necessary because 1) Band 7 is near the FIR SED peak powered by star formation (above and Fig.2), and 2) star-forming SEDs are inherently similar from the peak flux near 100 microns to the 300 micron rest wavelength we will observe (Rieke et al. 2009, Dai et al. 2012) This second point is true even if shorter wavelengths are dominated by quasar light (Beelen et al. 2008, Kirkpatrick et al. 2012). Therefore our SFR results are not sensitive to the SED. We also note that logical choices to increase our spectral coverage are not helpful: Band 9 is severely limited by weather constraints and flux calibration uncertainties, while Band 6 would add very little science information because it is far from the SED peak.

Band 7: The Band 7 frequency 300 GHz is highly sensitive, avoids telluric absorption, and corresponds to ~300 microns rest at z = 2.3, which is ideally near the peak of the spectral energy distribution of starbursting ULIRGs (e.g., Elbaz et al. 2002, Chary & Elbaz 2001) while also sufficiently longward of this peak where reprocessed quasar light (by hot dust) is negligible (Netzer et al. 2007, Farrah et al. 2007 and 2012, Lutz et al. 2008, Beelen et al. 2006, Kirkpatrick et al. 2012). Additional continuum points are not necessary because 1) Band 7 is near the FIR SED peak powered by star formation (above and Fig.2), and 2) star-forming SEDs are inherently similar from the peak flux near 100 microns to the 300 micron rest wavelength we will observe (Rieke et al. 2009, Dai et al. 2012) This second point is true even if shorter wavelengths are dominated by quasar light (Beelen et al. 2008, Kirkpatrick et al. 2012). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Luminous quasars are believed to mark a critical transition phase in massive galaxy evolution between an early intense ULIRG-like starburst and a passive red elliptical. We propose to test this evolution scheme by observing quasars across the transition. FeLoBAL quasars are a candidate young population with red colors, unusually powerful broad absorption line outflows, and large FIR luminosities indicating high star formation rates. However, the evolutionary status of FeLoBALs remains unclear due to uncertain FIR measurements and a critical lack of comparisons to non-FeLoBAL quasars. We propose to map the star formation in 8 FeLoBAL quasar hosts compared to a matched sample of 8 "normal" blue non-BAL quasars at redshift ~2.3 using Band 7 continuum observations with unprecedented sensitivity and spatial resolution (1.1 kpc on source). The mapping and comparative aspects of our program will provide unique tests of 1) the nature of star formation in z > 2 quasar host galaxies, 2) the relative youth of FeLoBAL quasars, 3) the feedback effects of FeLoBAL outflows on star formation in the hosts, and 4) the evolution paradigm of quasars as transition objects in massive galaxy formation.
